This year's Red Lion, the SA Navy (SAN) force preparation and readiness exercise which wrapped up on Friday (22 August), provided "countless training and learning opportunities" at naval bases and facilities nationally.

That was part of the thank you message Flag Officer Fleet (FOF) Rear Admiral Handsome Matsane had for participants on board the Valour class frigate SAS Amatola (F145). The exercise was officially deemed over with a ceremonial colours parade. In addition to naval personnel from the various units in and around Simon's Town, South Africa's unofficial naval capital, those based at Durban, Gqeberha, Saldanha and Tshwane were also part of the three-week exercise.

The exercise, Able Seaman Sisanda Xaba reported for the SA Navy, brought all "critical naval components" together in "a challenging environment" to test operational readiness of personnel and prime mission equipment (PME).

The other important component of Red Lion 2025 was the involvement of non-defence agencies such as the National Sea Rescue Institute (NSRI), SA Police Service (SAPS), Transnet and the Cape Town Metro by way of its metro police.

From a strictly SAN point of view, Red Lion was an opportunity to examine existing doctrines and standard operating procedures (SOPs) under Flag Officer Fleet command.

Apart from Simon's Town and False Bay, with three SAN platforms at sea, Naval Base (NB) Durban went through a simulated search and rescue (SAR) evolution with SA Air Force (SAAF) assets from 15 Squadron, the NSRI and Transnet.

While not reported, other SAN units including headquarters (previously SAS Immortelle) as well as those at East London and Gqeberha are believed to have brought their share to the overall success of the exercise.

"In an ever-changing world, being prepared will be our shield and training will be our spear. As such, Exercise Red Lion will continue to be the Fleet's measuring tool to determine our readiness," Matsane is reported as telling those at the ceremony marking exercise conclusion.

As a gesture of appreciation to Red Lion 2025 stakeholders, the SA Navy hosted representatives from the City of Cape Town, the local SA Police Service and the Institute of Maritime Technology on board the SAS Amatola on 20 August.

The frigate sailed under Fast Inshore Attack Craft drills along the coast of Muizenberg to Gordon's Bay and returned to False Bay. The Chief of the South African Navy, Vice-Admiral Monde Lobese, Matsane, and other senior officers used the opportunity to engage with the public stakeholders.

They also had an opportunity to witness the Maritime Reaction Squadron boarding boat conducting a Visit, Board, Search and Seizure capability demonstration.

SAS Amatola was joined by the two new Multi-Mission Inshore Patrol Vessels, SAS King Shaka Zulu and SAS Adam Kok III, for Red Lion 2025.

Together, they focused on training through the simulation of various scenarios such as crew responses to on-board fires, enemy threats or attacks, navigation and seamanship tasks, tactical operations such as Air Defence Drills, a simulated Replenishment at Sea, Officer of the Watch manoeuvres, Personnel Transfers and sea patrols.

On 15 August, all three SAN vessels were briefly joined in False Bay by the French offshore patrol vessel FS Auguste Techer (P781), which was making its way to its new home port of Port des Galets in Reunion.

On 24th July, at 08:00 in the morning, the Ro-Pax vessel 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' (IMO 9936587) arrived off Cape Town harbour, from Mindelo in the Cape Verde Islands. She entered Cape Town harbour and proceeded into the Duncan Dock, where she was placed alongside the Landing Wall. Cape Town, nor any other port in South Africa for that matter, receives visits from Ro-Pax (combined Roll-on/Roll-Off and Passenger) vessels, which clearly indicated this was merely a transit call for bunkers, stores and fresh provisions.

For those who know a little about the ocean going ferry requirements of Australia, they will be aware that the route between Tasmania and the Australian mainland of Victoria, via the Bass Strait, is the only such ferry route that generates the kind of daily traffic that requires a super ferry such as 'Spirit of Tasmania IV'.

Until 1985 the passenger service was operated by the government owned Australian National Lines (ANL), and when they pulled out of the service the Government of Tasmania created the 'Spirit of Tasmania' TT-Line, and stepped in to operate the service from Melbourne in Victoria, to Devonport in Tasmania.

As the service developed, they introduced two super ferries in 2002, namely the 1998 built sisterships 'Spirit of Tasmania I' (ex Superfast IV), and 'Spirit of Tasmania II' (ex Superfast III). After almost 20 years of splendid service across the Bass Strait, with ever increased traffic loads, and a change of Australian mainland departure/arrival port from Melbourne to Geelong, in Port Phillip Bay, the Tasmanian Government decided the time had come to order two newbuild replacements.

Ordered in April 2021, with her keel laid down in October 2022, and launched in October 2023, 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' was built at the Rauma Marine Construction (RMC) Oy. Shipyard, at Rauma in Finland at a cost of US$280 million (ZAR4.94 billion). She is 212 metres in length, with a beam of 31 metres, and a gross registered tonnage of 47,994 tons. Her delay into service from being completed by June 2024, and due for delivery in September 2024, was due to port facilities back in Devonport to accommodate the newer, and much larger vessels, was nowhere near complete, and still not finished to this day.

She is powered by four Wärtsilä 9L46DF nine cylinder, four stroke, Tier III compliant dual fuel main engines, capable of burning either Marine Diesel, or Liquid Natural Gas (LNG), and producing 13,819 bhp (10,305 kW) each, for a total of 55,276 bhp (41,220 kW), which drive two Kamewa controllable pitch propellers, linked to two Promas rudders, for a maximum speed of 31.5 knots, but with a published service speed of 26 knots.

Her onboard domestic power requirements are met by three Wärtsilä 20DF generators producing 1,440 kW each. For added maneouvrability she is fitted with two transverse bow thrusters, and two transverse stern thrusters and, for more comfortable seakeeping whilst crossing the notorious Bass Strait, 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' is fitted with two fin stabilisers.

With a total of eleven decks, of which three fixed decks are for vehicular traffic, both cars and freight trucks, and with two further hoistable decks for cars, providing 4,098 metres of lane metres, 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' provides enough space for up to 600 vehicles, with loading and unloading taking place by both bow, via a bow door and shoreside bridge, and via the stern through two stern ramps and shoreside bridges.

'Spirit of Tasmania IV' can carry a total of 1,800 passengers, who are looked after by a crew of 200. She provides a total of 301 cabins, over two decks, with 18 of these cabins being pet friendly, and possibly uniquely for Australia, a further two of these cabins being strongrooms for escorted prisoners. There are also 118 standard class recliner seats, and 47 business class recliner seats available in separate rest lounges.

Passenger facilities, which are over two further decks, include five restaurants, three cafés, four lounges, three bars, a reading room, two cinemas, a games zone, and a kids zone. There are kennels provided for pets, and a separate pet walking deck area. For any logistical needs, or requirements, such as pilotage, police, medevac, or search and rescue, she has a helicopter landing deck, with a helicopter 'D' value of 17 metres, and a maximum weight limit of 7 tons.

Currently the Spirit of Tasmania ferry service operates a single daily round trip voyage, year round, between Geelong and Devonport, with up to two round trips in the high summer months. In 2024 the service carried over 450,000 passengers, which is an average of 1,233 passengers per voyage, giving an indication of how important the Spirit of Tasmania service is for the Tasmanian economy.

In comparison between the operational statistics of the current ferries 'Spirit of Tasmania I' and 'Spirit of Tasmania II' (29,000 grt, 1,400 passengers, 500 vehicles), the introduction of the new 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' and the still to come 'Spirit of Tasmania V' will bring a capacity increase of 43% in numbers of passengers able to be carried, and 39% of freight traffic able to be carried. The introduction of 'Spirit of Tasmania V', which is the second sister ship of 'Spirit of Tasmania IV', is scheduled to take place in 2026.

Uniquely, 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' is one of less than twenty commercial vessels which fly the Australian Red Duster, and are registered in an Australian port, in this case she is registered in the port of Devonport in Tasmania. She is owned by TT-Line Co. Pty. Ltd., of Devonport, and operated by Spirit of Tasmania, and managed by TT-Line Tasmania, all of which full under the overall ownership of the Government of Tasmania.

Separately, but not connected to the Spirit of Tasmania operation, there are also a minimum of two daily freight only voyages, between Melbourne and two ports in Tasmania, carried out by pure Ro-Ro vessels, one of which is currently 'Liekut', which positioned as a newbuild from Germany to Australia, with a bunker call in Cape Town on 9th March 2021. Prior to her call in Cape Town she had used her maiden positioning voyage to gain some income for her owners, by carrying and discharging 389 European built commercial freight vehicles in Walvis Bay.

On completion in Finland, and with the Devonport port facilities still being incomplete, the Tasmanian Government tried to get a short term charter for 'Spirit of Tasmania IV', but by October 2024 nothing was forthcoming. With the normal winter freezing of the Baltic Sea approaching, and with 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' not having any ice classification, the decision was taken to position her to an ice free port for lay-up. In late November 2024 she departed from the shipyard, and headed for the port of Leith in Scotland, where she arrived on 3rd December.

The Devonport facilities, which included increasing the quay length to accommodate the new vessels, which were almost 20 metres longer than their predecessors, was originally budgeted for an outlay of AUS$90 million (ZAR1.03 billion), but by mid-2025 had been revised upwards to a phenomenal AUS$495 million (ZAR5.67 billion). With the completion of the Devonport port facilities now scheduled for October 2026, and with lay-up berthing fees in Leith having reached AUS$6.4 million (ZAR73.23 million), the decision was taken to bring 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' to Australia, with a sailing date from Scotland scheduled for June 2025.

After fixing an issue with her LNG fuelling system, 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' sailed from Leith on 30th June 2025, initially bound for Gibraltar for bunker and logistics call, where she arrived on 5th July, sailing on 6th July for Mindelo in the Cape Verde Islands, before heading to Cape Town. Her time in Cape Town stretched to 36 hours, and she finally sailed at 20:00 on the evening of 25th July, but only as far as the Table Bay anchorage, where she remained for a short period of 16 hours, and at midday on 26th July, she departed Table Bay, with her AIS indicating that her next call was to be Port Louis in Mauritius.

Her trans Indian Ocean transit voyage had 'Spirit of Tasmania IV' arrive at Port Louis on 2nd August, and after a stay of just 21 hours, she departed on 3rd August for her run to Fremantle, in Western Australia, where she arrived in home waters at 08:00 in the morning of 12th August, where she had to endure a mandatory minimum three day stay in Fremantle, in order to both clear customs, and complete documentation, for the importation of a new Australian vessel.

She was ready to continue her voyage on 15th August, but she only went as far as the Kwinana anchorage, off Fremantle, where she remained until 09:00 on 17th August, when she finally sailed for Tasmania. She crossed the Great Australian Bight and at 09:00 on the morning of 23rd August, she sailed up the Derwent River, and came alongside in the port of Hobart, after a long voyage of 14,857 nautical miles.

She will remain alongside in Hobart, ostensibly to train her new crew in every facet of shipboard operations, and emergency drills, as well as to undertake the final fitting out of Tasmanian furniture, and local artwork and decorations throughout the passenger decks. In October it is planned that she will sail from Hobart, to her new home in Devonport for berthing trials, and if all goes to plan she will start her service on the 242 nautical mile route between Devonport and Geelong, taking 9.5 hours to cross the Bass Strait in Summer, and taking a slower 11.5 hours in Winter.

* AI Talent Development: A landmark initiative will train 30,000 African AI specialists over the next three years, in collaboration with the University of Tokyo and African universities.

Angolan President João Lourenço, co-chair of the summit, emphasised the urgency of affordable capital access, calling current borrowing costs "a persistent barrier" to Africa's growth.

For African maritime and logistics stakeholders, the proposed economic zone could reshape trade corridors across the Indian Ocean rim -- from Durban to Mombasa, Maputo to Mumbai. The AI training initiative, meanwhile, offers a rare opportunity to embed digital capacity into port operations, customs systems, and regional supply chains.

* Green Port Technologies: Climate-focused funding could support shore power, emissions tracking, and smart energy grids in strategic terminals.

This zone proposal isn't just geopolitical -- it's a logistics blueprint. For African ports, it offers a chance to leapfrog legacy systems and embed next-generation infrastructure into regional trade. The challenge will be ensuring local ownership, skills transfer, and sustainable financing.

The deal is seen as a reaffirmation of both companies' commitment to restoring rail performance, driving export growth, and promoting sustainability in the mining and transport sectors.

Maiden arrivals into any South African port, of any vessel on a maiden voyage, are always an occasion of excitement for the casual maritime observer. It is even more so when the vessel is of a more specialised nature than the normal cargo carrier, and especially so when her cargo is both visible, and very much a pointer to where the world is headed in terms of future energy needs, but not a direction it would seem that South Africa appears determined to take.

On 8th August, at 08:00 in the morning, the gearless project cargo carrier 'Eco Triumph' (IMO 9938717) arrived off Cape Town from Singapore. She entered Cape Town harbour, proceeding into the Duncan Dock, and went alongside the outer Landing Wall. Such a berth points to her visit being more than just a quick logistics call for bunkers, stores and provisions. It is not unknown for vessels on maiden voyages to have gremlins appear in new equipment, and within the onboard technology, that requires shoreside assistance to sort the problem out.

Built in 2025 by the Dayang Offshore shipyard at Jiangsu in China, 'Eco Triumph' is powered by a single MaK 9M32C nine cylinder, four stroke, main engine producing 4,022 bhp (2,999 kW), and driving a nozzled controllable pitch propeller for a maximum service speed of 14 knots. Domestic power is provided by two AGCO generators providing 182 kW each. For added manoeuvrability she is fitted with a bow transverse thruster.

Designed to carry large outsize cargo, she is gearless which gives her a large obstruction free deck for the carriage of project freight, such as that she was carrying on this voyage. She has a single hold with dimensions of 97.3 metres by 14.3 metres, with a cargo carrying capacity of 14,252 m3, and a cargo deck strength of 15 tons/m2. She is fitted with pontoon hatch covers, which are moved by an onboard travelling pontoon gantry crane.

For her outsize cargo requirements, the cargo hold floor area of 'Eco Triumph' is 2,590 m2, and her deck offers free space of 2,100 m2. To allow for multiple cargoes to be carried, her cargo hold can be split up by the use of up to four moveable bulkheads, and by up to three separate tweendecks. Although she has a container carrying capacity of 492 TEU, strangely she is fitted with no reefer deck plugs whatsoever, so cannot carry any refrigerated containers.

She is the sixth of a class of ten sisterships, known as the OTECO 9000 class, with the first sistership coming into service in 2023, and the final sistership being scheduled to come into service in 2026. Owned and operated by Briese Schiffahrts GmbH, of Leer in Germany, as shown by the company logo on her funnel, 'Eco Triumph' is managed by Briese Chartering GmbH, also of Leer in Germany, and as advertised along the length of her hull. Her design to accommodate the longest deck cargo possible based on her length, has resulted in her accommodation being placed on top of her bow, which will make for an uncomfortable ride in a head sea.

After a stay alongside in Cape Town of 60 hours, which seemed to confirm that she was receiving some shoreside maintenance, or technical, assistance, in addition to any bunker uplift, stores loading, and fresh provisions replenishment, 'Eco Triumph' was ready to continue her maiden voyage. She sailed from Cape Town at 20:00 in the evening of 10th August, now bound onward to the Baltic port of Swinoujscie, in Poland.

As each sistership of the class has come into service, the majority of them began their commercial career by loading a full cargo of wind turbine components, with hubs and nacelles being loaded in their holds, and with a corresponding full deck cargo of wind turbine blades to accompany the hold components. In this instance, 'Eco Triumph' is not any different, as she was carrying a full deck cargo of 25 wind turbine blades, which had been loaded in Dongzao in China for her maiden voyage back to Europe.

The Dongzao port complex is one of the closest ports to the City of Nantong, which has been making strong efforts to build a national level wind power generation and equipment manufacturing production base in recent years. More than 80 percent of one of the Nantong based Wind turbine blade producers are currently being exported to overseas destinations from Dongzao Port. South Africa is not much likely to be amongst the export destination mix!

In June 2025 the port of Swinoujscie, which is the destination port of 'Eco Triumph' opened a new terminal dedicated for the unloading, storage, and loading, of components used in the construction of offshore wind farm. These components include monopile foundations, turbine towers, nacelles, blade, and cabling, as well as offshore electrical substation topsides weighing up to 24,000 tons. The new terminal will facilitate the installation of more than 80 wind turbines per year in the Baltic Sea.

The new terminal had already been announced as the new BC-Wind Project installation facility, able to support wind turbines up to a capacity of 15 MW. The BC-Wind offshore wind farm, which is located 150 nautical miles east of Swinoujscie, and 12 nautical miles offshore from Choczewo, in the province of Pomerania. Choczewo is the location where the offshore wind farm production will connect with the Polish National Grid.

Construction of the BC-Wind wind farm is now only just getting underway, and will initially comprise 26 Siemens-Gamesa 14-236 wind turbines, to give the field an installed capacity output of 390 MW, capable of providing power to 488,000 households. Each turbine will produce 14 kW of electrical power, with the field increasing to 31 turbines, producing 500 MW, and becoming fully operational in 2028.

There is currently no fully operational wind farm operational in Polish waters, with the Baltic Power wind farm scheduled to become the first one in 2026. The Baltic Power wind farm, which is also located 12 nautical miles off Choczewo, began development in 2024, and will comprise 76 Vestas V236 wind turbines, each producing 15 MW of power, and giving an installed output of 1.2 GW capable of providing power to 1.5 million households in Poland.

The cost of the development and construction of the Baltic Power wind farm is US$5.54 billion (ZAR96.67 billion), and will provide 3% of the Polish national energy requirements, with the field output also coming ashore at Choczewo. The Polish government estimates that, by 2020, 30% of national energy requirements will come from renewable energy sources.

The destination port of 'Eco Triumph', Swinoujscie, is also the main discharge port for all wind farm components for onshore wind farms, as well as offshore wind farms. All components for the onshore Rzepin wind farm, located inland and 100 miles south of Szcezin, were imported through Swinoujscie. The wind farm consists of 29 Vestas V90 wind turbines, each providing 2 MW, to give the field an installed output of 58 MW, capable of providing power to 70,000 households.

Briese Chartering GmbH is a major shipper of Vestas wind turbine components, including those wind turbine blades produced in their factory located at Tianjin in China. In 2025 at the recent Vestas Shipping and Surveyor Summit, Vestas awarded Briese Chartering GmbH the 'Best Shipping Line' award for handling Vestas cargo worldwide. Interestingly, at the same event, with the Polish connection with the current voyage of 'Eco triumph', Vestas awarded their 'Best Shipping Agent' award to the Polish company of Morska Agencja Gdynia Sp.Z.O.O.

Namport pulls back from Lüderitz oil & gas supply base after environmental and political pressure

Terry Hutson

Africa Ports & Ships

Durban

The promise of transforming Namibia's southern harbour town of Lüderitz into a fully-fledged offshore energy service hub has hit a major setback. Namport, the country's state-owned ports authority, has abruptly cancelled a tender that would have brought in private developers to design, build, finance and operate a dedicated oil and gas supply base.

The cancellation, announced on 15 August in a brief public notice, stunned industry watchers. Only days earlier Namport had invited bids under a DBOOT (Design, Build, Own, Operate, Transfer) concession, signalling intent to fast-track port facilities capable of serving the booming Orange Basin oil discoveries.

Behind the dry notice, however, lies a swirl of environmental and heritage concerns. Local media report that confusion over the project's Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) played a decisive role. Stakeholders raised objections to the proposed use of land around Shark Island, a site imbued with deep historical sensitivity as well as ecological importance.

Namport acknowledged the concerns, saying it did not want to risk compromising the ongoing EIA process. For Lüderitz, which sits on hard bedrock and has limited back-up land, the technical challenges of dredging and reclamation are already formidable. Adding the weight of heritage objections made the process more politically charged.

The decision reflects a growing tension in Namibia's energy expansion: balancing the rush to monetise offshore discoveries with commitments to environmental stewardship and community trust.

The project has also been caught up in political undercurrents. Earlier this year, reports surfaced that a Swapo-linked company, Guinas Investments, had approached Namport with an unsolicited N$3 billion proposal to develop the base. The authority rebuffed the overture, citing its obligation to run an open and transparent procurement process.

The link between ruling-party interests and major energy infrastructure cast a shadow over the project, fuelling public suspicion about who might ultimately benefit. By pulling the tender so soon after launch, Namport may be signalling that it wants to reset the process -- and reduce the perception that politically connected entities could gain an inside track.

The timing is awkward. International oil majors are stepping up drilling campaigns in the Orange Basin, and Namibia has set an ambitious goal of achieving first oil by 2030. Walvis Bay, the country's main port, can absorb some of the demand for offshore support, but its distance from the southern fields adds cost and time penalties. Lüderitz was being positioned as the logical staging point for supply vessels, storage yards, and rig-support services.

Had the project gone ahead, it was expected to unlock around N$4 billion (US$222 million) in investment for quay extensions, land reclamation and warehousing. It also promised jobs and skills development in marine logistics, mechanical trades and HSE management -- opportunities that would have diversified Lüderitz's economy beyond its reliance on fishing and tourism.

For now, those prospects are on hold.

Namport has left the door open to a revised tender, suggesting that the concept is not abandoned but in need of recalibration. Any relaunch is likely to demand greater clarity on berth-depth targets, dredging methods, environmental safeguards, and how heritage sites will be protected. Equally, investors will look for transparency in tariffs, operating rules, and guarantees that local communities will see meaningful benefit.

The cancellation underlines a broader reality: as Namibia's energy story gathers pace, infrastructure decisions will increasingly be judged not only on technical and financial merits, but also on their political optics and environmental footprint.

For Lüderitz, the pause may be temporary. But whether the town can still claim its place as a southern energy hub now depends on Namport's ability to rebuild trust and chart a more transparent, environmentally credible path forward.

Unlocking the Rails: South Africa's freight corridors and the technical realities of reform

By Terry Hutson

Africa Ports & Ships

Durban

The announcement by Transnet and the Department of Transport that 11 companies have been conditionally awarded access to operate across 41 rail routes [see here] marks a watershed moment in South Africa's freight logistics landscape.

While the headlines focus on liberalisation and private sector inclusion, the deeper story lies in the technical complexity and strategic nuance of the corridors themselves.

Each of South Africa's six freight corridors presents a distinct operational challenge -- shaped by terrain, commodity type, infrastructure legacy, and rolling stock requirements. Understanding these corridors is essential not only for grasping the significance of the slot awards, but for anticipating the future of rail freight in the region.

The North Corridor, anchored by the Ermelo-Richards Bay coal artery, is the backbone of South Africa's bulk export economy. With train lengths exceeding 3.7 km and axle loads pushing 26-30 tons, this corridor demands high-horsepower electric locomotives like the Class 19E and 21E.

Precision scheduling and regenerative braking systems are non-negotiable. It's no surprise that only seasoned operators with deep technical capacity are likely to be awarded slots here.

Similarly, the Iron Ore Corridor from Sishen to Saldanha is a single-purpose, ultra-heavy haul route. It operates with distributed power and radio train integrity systems, moving upwards of 60 million tonnes annually. This corridor is less about flexibility and more about brute efficiency -- a closed loop that tolerates no margin for error.

The Cape Corridor, linking Hotazel to Port Elizabeth & Ngqura, is manganese-rich but infrastructure-challenged. It requires dual-voltage or hybrid locomotives capable of navigating long distances and variable terrain. The Central Corridor, meanwhile, is a hybrid route connecting Gauteng to the Northern Cape, handling containers, chemicals, and automotive cargo. Its complexity lies in its junction-heavy layout and commodity diversity.

The Container Corridor, running between Durban and Gauteng, is South Africa's intermodal lifeline. It demands high-speed electric traction, tight port-terminal integration, and time-sensitive scheduling. While technically less demanding than the bulk corridors, its urban interface and congestion levels make it a logistical chessboard.

The Northeast Corridor, which includes the Komatipoort-Maputo route, is emerging as a strategic gateway for regional trade. It's here that Grindrod appears to have secured its slot -- a logical move given its terminal footprint in Matola and its refurbished fleet of mid-weight locomotives repatriated from Sierra Leone.

With moderate gradients and manageable axle loads, this corridor offers a realistic entry point for private operators without the need for ultra-heavy haul specs.

South Africa's rail corridors were shaped by colonial-era mining priorities and post-war industrial expansion.

The North Corridor emerged in the 1970s as a dedicated coal export route, while the Iron Ore Corridor was purpose-built in the 1970s to serve the Sishen mines.

The Cape Corridor gained prominence in the 1990s with the rise of manganese exports, though its infrastructure lagged behind demand.

The Container Corridor reflects the shift toward intermodal logistics in the 2000s, linking Durban's port to Gauteng's inland terminals.

The Central Corridor has long served as a multi-commodity backbone, but its complexity has often deterred private investment.

The Northeast Corridor, once a modest regional link, is now a strategic gateway to Mozambique -- a transformation driven partly by Grindrod and DP World's terminal investments and regional trade growth.

With the slot liberalisation now underway, these corridors are poised to evolve from state-dominated arteries into competitive logistics platforms. The challenge lies not just in access, but in operational readiness, safety compliance, and infrastructure compatibility.

Welfare of Indian seafarers and families: D-G Shipping India and ISWAN MoU

Edited by Paul Ridgway

Africa Ports & Ships

London

As part of the 75-Year Commemorative Events, the Directorate General of Shipping (DG Shipping), India, and the London-based International Seafarers' Welfare and Assistance Network (ISWAN) have formally signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to establish a framework of cooperation to enhance the welfare, training, safety, and wellbeing of Indian seafarers and their families through collaborative initiatives. This was reported at the end of August.

This partnership reinforces the shared commitment of both organisations to support Indian seafarers and their families through dedicated outreach, education, and crisis response mechanisms.

Key areas of collaboration under the MoU include:

* Awareness and Induction Training for cadets and ratings through ISWAN's Seafarers' Education and Awareness Sessions (SEAS) in DG Shipping-approved Maritime Training Institutes.

* Promotion of Port Welfare Committees under MLC 2006 to improve port-level support for visiting seafarers in Indian ports.

* Implementation of ISWAN's Family Outreach Programme, which provides guidance and emotional support to the families of seafarers and helps to improve communication strategies which encourage to build a stronger and healthy relationship.

* Joint promotion of ISWAN's 'Safe at sea...it takes all of us!' campaign to improve gender safety and allyship at sea.

* Integration of ISWAN's 24/7 multilingual SeafarerHelp helpline within DG Shipping's upcoming grievance redressal platform. ISWAN is prepared and will endeavour to facilitate help in situations like: abuse or bullying or harassment, health issues - both physical and mental health, maritime piracy and threats at sea, abandonment and cases of fraudulent crewing agents, personal and family problems, general information seeking, missing, and suicide cases.

* Organisation of joint regional events to raise awareness on mental health, safety, and wellbeing in the maritime sector.

This landmark MoU brings together regulatory and welfare expertise to deliver coordinated support for seafarers, including emotional, psycho-social, and practical assistance. It recognises the importance of a seafarer's family and shore-side support networks, especially during crisis situations such as abandonment, psychological distress, or harassment at sea.

Speaking on the collaboration, Shri Shyam Jagannathan, IAS, the Director General of Shipping, said: "This MoU marks a significant milestone in our continued efforts to safeguard the welfare and wellbeing of Indian seafarers and their families.

"By working closely with ISWAN, we aim to strengthen support systems, enhance awareness, and ensure timely assistance during times of need. Together, we are committed to creating a safer, healthier, and more supportive maritime environment, both at sea and ashore. This partnership will help us build resilience within the seafaring community and ensure that no seafarer or their family feels unsupported."

Mr Chirag Bahri, International Operations Manager, ISWAN, said they are honoured to formalise their collaboration with the Directorate General of Shipping, India, through this MoU.

"Indian seafarers form a vital part of the global maritime workforce, and their welfare -- along with that of their families -- remains at the heart of ISWAN's mission," he said.

"This partnership will allow us to work more closely with the maritime administration to address critical welfare challenges, provide timely assistance, and deliver impactful programmes such as our helplines, awareness sessions, and outreach initiatives. Together, we can ensure that every seafarer has access to the support and resources they need, both during their time at sea and when ashore."

The MoU is effective for three years and will be jointly monitored through a designated Working Group.

At Trinity House a new Director of Navigational Requirements and Policy - Captain Des Donworth

At IFSMA a Secretary General designate - Captain Andrew Cook

At Trinity House

Trinity House London reported on 8 August that Captain Des Donworth MA FRIN FCMI RN (Ret'd) is to succeed Commander Nigel Hare FRIN RN as the Director of Navigational Requirements and Policy.

Captain Donworth will officially take up his role on 15 September 2025.

Captain Donworth joins Trinity House with an exceptional maritime background. Since beginning his career in the Royal Navy in 1992 as a Seaman Officer, he has dedicated his professional life to navigation -- serving at sea in some of the world's most demanding environments, from the ice of Antarctica to the heat of the Arabian Gulf.

His operational credibility is built on years of practical experience and leadership. He has commanded ships on NATO deployments, served as Head of Navigation at the United States Naval Academy, and led maritime advisory missions in Libya and Iraq. Recently appointed a Fellow of the Royal Institute of Navigation and as a former Chair of the Navigating and Direction Officers' Association, Captain Donworth brings a wealth of experience and a deep passion for the craft and science of safe and effective navigation.

"It is an enormous honour for me to be taking over the role of Director of Navigational Requirement and Policy from Nigel Hare," Captain Donworth commented. "I bring my experience in the Royal Navy to Trinity House but recognise that I have a new world to understand and I am genuinely looking forward to working to support and shape the future of navigational requirements and policy."

At IFSMA

On 30 July the International Federation of Ship Masters' Associations (IFSMA) announced the appointment of Captain Andrew Cook FNI as Secretary General designate to succeed Commodore Jim Scorer FNI RN who will be retiring as Secretary General at the end of the year.

As a former ship Master, Andrew Cook brings a wealth of experience in global ship operations, ship management, crew management and crew welfare.

He is a long-standing Fellow of the Nautical Institute and has sat on influential industry working groups such as the INTERTANKO Human Element committee.

Currently Captain Cook is working alongside Commodore Scorer and will be preparing to lead the IFSMA team at IMO and at other forums in January 2026.

At IMO, IFSMA occupies a seat as a non-governmental organisation (NGO) in consultative status with the organization.

Regarding his appointment Captain Cook said: "It is an honour to be appointed as the next IFSMA Secretary General and to promote the best interests of the world's ship masters within an ever-changing industry that faces numerous challenges."

data.content: (RTT新闻) - 由于俄罗斯和乌克兰和平协议的前景减弱，加上焦点转向稍后发布的关键美国通胀数据，这可能提供更多关于美联储利率展望的线索，欧洲股市周五可能普遍低开。 在周四俄罗斯导弹和无人机袭击乌克兰首都基辅的公寓楼，造成至少23人死亡，其中包括4名儿童后，美国总统唐纳德·特朗普表示，“他对这一消息并不满意，但也不感到惊讶”。 在贸易方面，欧盟表示已通过了草案法规，取消对美国工业商品的所有关税，并对一些美国农产品和海产品给予优惠待遇。 在经济数据方面，今天美国的核心个人消费支出（PCE）通胀和支出数据将受到关注，此外还有芝加哥地区商业活动和消费者信心的数据。 美联储理事克里斯托弗·沃勒呼吁在9月即将召开的会议上降息，并补充说他“完全预期”未来会有更多的降息，以使美联储的政策利率更接近中性水平。 由于对美联储独立性的担忧加剧以及对即将降息的预期增强，美元本月可能下跌2%。 美联储理事莉莎·库克因特朗普试图解雇她而提起诉讼，这可能引发对美国央行独立性的潜在法律争端。 黄金在亚洲交易中小幅下跌，但因降息预期上升，预计本周将上涨。石油在前一交易日上涨后小幅下跌。 美国股市在周四晚些时候上涨，投资者对备受期待的AI巨头英伟达的财报消息以及第二季度国内生产总值（GDP）意外增长的数据作出了反应。 第二季度实际GDP增长了3.3%，高于此前报告的3.0%的增长，主要反映了投资和消费者支出的向上修正。 另外的数据表明，上周美国首次申请失业救济人数降至229000，表明裁员率较低。 标普500指数上涨0.3%，创下新的收盘高点，道琼斯工业平均指数上涨0.2%，科技股为主的纳斯达克综合指数上涨0.5%。 周四，欧洲股市表现不一，英伟达警告中国销售的持续不确定性。 泛欧斯托克600指数下跌0.2%。德国DAX指数小幅下跌，英国富时100指数下跌0.4%。 法国CAC 40指数在早些时候大幅下跌后小幅上涨0.2%，因市场担忧政治和财政危机加深。

data.title: Param Sundari 电影评论：爱、欢笑与所有的情感——年度浪漫喜剧之作
data.summary: Param Sundari是一部由Tushar Jalota执导的浪漫喜剧电影，主演包括Sidharth Malhotra和Janhvi Kapoor等。该片以数字时代人们的爱情观为背景，强调倾听内心的重要性，倡导真实的情感连接。影片时长136分钟，获得了4星评价。Param Sundari是一部温馨、友好的作品，提醒人们爱情和连接才是爱情最真挚的形式。
data.content:
Director - Tushar Jalota, Cast - Sidharth Malhotra, Janhvi Kapoor, Renji Panicker, Siddhartha Shankar, Manjot Singh, Sanjay Kapoor, Inayat Verma, Runtime - 136 Minutes

Rating - 4.

In a world where love is filtered through screens and swipes, Param Sundari is a romance about the beauty of listening to your heart. Digital boom has definitely shrunk the world to the palm of our hands, but kept us repeatedly distanced from ourselves, and this film is a warm, amiable prod to the return to what really matters, love and connection is its truest form!

When love is measured by compatibility ratings and prescribed by dating apps, the film gently and genuinely reminds us that no algorithm or AI or modern app, can quantify chemistry, timing, or genuine connection.

From the very first frame of Param Sundari, you know you're in for something special. There's a certain magic that can't be faked, that hum of creative harmony when acting, direction, writing, and every technical element breathe in sync. In this modern day and age, with notification buzzing through the day, it's rare, it's precious, and it's dazzling and soothing at the same time.

Director Tushar Jalota's feature isn't just a film -- it's a warm, beating heart projected onto the screen. Like stepping into a lucid dream woven from memory and feelings, ParamSundari is a soul-soothing experience that manages to feel both timeless and strikingly new. Emotions cannot be faked, they are felt, and this one is a whole kaleidoscope of emotions, colors, moods, and connecting with another human being.

Though, the film takes the traditional opposites-attract route of a North-meets-South love story, with a little help of an app, but it's elevated by a warm screenplay, a sizzling central couple, and a soundtrack that brims with emotion.

The storyline revolves around Param (Sidharth Malhotra), a tech-savvy, smooth Delhi businessman who has dreams of investing in a slick app for meeting your "soul-mate."

When Param's dad (Sanjay Kapoor), tired of his shenanigans, dares him to use his own app to find a soulmate in a month, and we're introduced to Sundari (Janhvi Kapoor), a down-to-earth and feisty Malayali woman whose warmth and authenticity cannot be programmed into boxes. What follows is a snappy and surprisingly profound examination of digital love versus true feeling.

Swooning romance of leading duo, sets the movie ablaze. Something that started over an app, soon turns into one adorable mess of emotions, love, faith and heart, which certainly cannot controlled, only felt!

Actor Sidharth Malhotra adds charisma, perfect comic timing, and surprising emotional depth to Param. But it is Janhvi Kapoor who truly steals the show with the most powerful performance of her career to date as Sundari. Her interpretation is assertive, nuanced, and never tips into stereotype -- she isn't merely acting; she is living the part. Whether it's the accent, the clothing, or the attitude, she nails every element of the role with remarkable authenticity. This is a defining performance that firmly establishes Janhvi as a force to be reckoned with.

The chemistry between Param and Sundarri is just crackling that shifts from stammering sparks to slow burning candor. Theirs is a love that is at once new and ancient, a love today's young people -- perpetually swiping for approval -- will deeply understand.

The supporting cast adds texture and charm, Sanjay Kapoor with his impeccable comic timing and effortless charm, he brings laugh-out-loud moments just when things get intense. His quirky expressions and one-liners add a delightful dose of fun to the otherwise high-stakes drama. Actor Manjot Singh is hilarious, Inayat Verma is a scene-stealer, and Renji Panicker and Siddhartha Shankar bring sincerity to Sundari's world.

The film is visually stunning, from the concrete gloss of Delhi's start-up scene to the lush, unfiltered beauty of Kerala's backwaters, the film travels a physical and emotional distance. The production design is sharp, and the costumes -- particularly Janhvi's elegant saris and Param's laid-back sophistication -- reflect character without trying too hard.

The music of the film is outstanding, the film's emotional backbone. With six standout tracks, the soundtrack does the heavy lifting of bringing every romantic beat to life. Whether it's the mischievous Pardesiya, the sensual Bheegi Saree, the staccato Danger, or the heartbreakingly lovely Sunn Mere Yaar Ve and Chand Kagaz Ka, every number hits the spot. Title song Sundari Ke Pyar Mein is already a chartbuster -- and rightly so.

Produced by Dinesh Vijan under Maddock Films, the beauty of the film lies in how honestly it reflects a generation that's gotten a little too comfortable outsourcing love to algorithms. It doesn't preach -- it feels, breathes and offers an experience of love, being in love, what is love, but does it gently. It reminds us that love isn't something you swipe for or add to cart; it's messy, risky, deeply human!

Param Sundari is not just a movie, it's a chance to fall in love all over again!!

从未来趋势来看，随着人工智能和大数据技术的进步，如何更好地理解和利用这些技术来促进人与人之间的深度连接，而非仅仅作为情感交流的替代品，将成为一个重要的研究方向。电影《Param Sundari》通过其温暖而真诚的故事，为我们提供了一种思考未来科技发展方向的新视角，即如何在科技发展的同时，保护和促进真实的人际关系。

DIGITALIST GROUP'S HALF-YEAR REVIEW, 1 JANUARY-30 JUNE 2025 (Not audited)

SUMMARY

April-June 2025 (comparable figures for 2024 in parentheses):

Turnover: EUR 4.6 million (EUR 4.0 million), increase: 14.0%. EBITDA: EUR -0.2 million (EUR -0.7 million), -5.3% of turnover (-18.2%).EBIT: EUR -0.4 million (EUR -0.7 million), -8.3% of turnover (-18.1%). Net income: EUR -1.0 million (EUR -1.5 million), -21.8% of turnover (-37.6%).Earnings per share (diluted and undiluted): EUR -0.00 (EUR -0.00)*.

January-June 2025 (comparable figures for 2024 in parentheses):

Turnover: EUR 9.0 million (EUR 7.9 million), increase: 14.8%.EBITDA: EUR -0.4 million (EUR -1.1 million), -4.2% of turnover (-14.4%). EBIT: EUR -0.6 million (EUR -1.3 million), -7.1% of turnover (-17.0%). Net income: EUR -2.0 million (EUR -2.6 million), -22.4% of turnover (-32.4%). Earnings per share (diluted and undiluted): EUR -0.00 (EUR -0.00).* Cash flow from operations: EUR -1.3 million (EUR -1.3 million). Number of employees at the end of the review period: 123 (127), decrease of 3.1%.

*The information is presented as of 30 June, 2025, before the share consolidation on 15 August, 2025.

Future prospects

In 2025, it is expected that turnover and EBITDA will improve in comparison with 2024.

CEO's review

The first half of 2025 shows improvement compared to the same period last year. Revenue and earnings have developed in the right direction, but the pace of improvement is slower than we anticipated, and we are still some way from profitability.

We have been able to generate growth despite the challenging market climate. This has been made possible by maintaining long-standing client relationships while also winning new assignments. Sweden remains our strongest market, and in Finland we achieved growth even as increased price sensitivity has put pressure on margins across the industry.

Operational efficiency and cost discipline remain key priorities. We achieved operating expense savings of approximately EUR 0.3 million in the first half compared to the same period last year. While these measures are beginning to show results, continued focus is needed to reach profitability.

During the period we also advanced our work within applied AI. The Digitalist Private AI Hub has now been launched under the brand name Stacken.ai, and we have initiated our first AI transformation assignments, for example with Utbildningsradion and Linköping Municipality in Sweden. These are early but important steps in building a service area that we believe will rapidly grow in importance for our clients.

I am grateful to all our employees for their dedication and resilience, and to our clients for the trust they continue to place in us. The road ahead will not be without challenges, but with steady progress and a clear focus we are building the foundations for a stronger, profitable, and more sustainable Digitalist Group.

/ CEO, Magnus Leijonborg

SEGMENT REPORTING

Digitalist Group reports its business in a single segment.

TURNOVER

In the second quarter, the Group's turnover was EUR 4.6 million (EUR 4.0 million), which is 14.0% more than in the previous year.

The Group's turnover for the review period was EUR 9.0 million (EUR 7.9 million), an increase of 14.8% compared to the previous year as a result of growth in the Finnish and Swedish operations. The appreciation of the SEK contributed approximately +2 percentage points to revenue growth. After challenging years, revenue in the Finnish operations has also begun to grow, and the development has been similar in both countries during the first half of the year. However, the uncertain economic situation continues to affect client decisions and slows down the initiation of new projects.

The turnover outside Finland was 69% (70%).

RESULT

In the second quarter, EBITDA was EUR -0.2 million (EUR -0.7 million), EBIT was EUR -0.4 million (EUR -0.7 million), and profit before taxes was EUR -1.0 million (EUR -1.5 million). Sales growth and EUR 0.2 million in savings in operating expenses compared to the second quarter of last year improved EBITDA. Net income for the second quarter amounted to EUR -1.0 million (EUR -1.5 million), earnings per share* was EUR -0.00 (EUR -0.00).

In the review period, EBITDA came to EUR -0.4 million (EUR -1.1 million), EBIT was EUR -0.6 million (EUR -1.3 million), and profit before taxes was EUR -2.0 million (EUR -2.5 million). Sales growth and EUR 0.3 million savings in operating expenses improved the EBITDA. Conversely, personnel expenses increased EUR 0.2 million and subcontracting expenses and purchases increased EUR 0.4 million compared to the comparison period. The net financial income and expenses were EUR -1.4 million (EUR -1.2 million). Financial items were negatively impacted by exchange gains booked on the balance sheet. Net income for the financial period amounted to EUR -2.0 million (EUR -2.6 million), earnings per share* was EUR 0.00 (EUR -0.00) and cash flow from operating activities per share* was EUR -0.00 (EUR -0.00).

*The information is presented as of June 30, 2025, before the share consolidation on August 15, 2025.

RETURN ON EQUITY

The Group's shareholders' equity amounted to EUR -39.4 million (EUR -35.6 million). The Group's equity considering the capital loans was EUR -11.9 million (EUR -16.5 million). More information on capital loans is in the section of the balance sheet and financing. Return on equity (ROE) was negative. Return on investment (ROI) was -24.1 (-89.7) per cent.

INVESTMENTS

There were no significant investments (EUR 0.0 million).

BALANCE SHEET AND FINANCING

The balance sheet total was EUR 10.2 million (EUR 10.3 million). The equity ratio was -392.2% (-345.1%).

At the end of the review period, the Group's liquid assets totalled EUR 0.1 million (EUR 0.3 million).

At the end of the review period the Group's interest-bearing liabilities amounted to EUR 42.8 million (EUR 36.6 million). The Group's balance sheet recognised EUR 11.2 million (EUR 11.4 million) in loans from financial institutions, including the overdrafts in use. IFRS 16 leasing debts were EUR 0.8 million (EUR 0.7 million).

The loans from related parties amount to EUR 30.8 million (EUR 24.5 million). EUR 27.5 million (EUR 19.1 million) related party loans were capital loans, EUR 0.0 million (EUR 3.9 million) were convertible bonds. Other loans to related parties were EUR 3.3 million (EUR 1.5 million). The change is due to the conversion of convertible bonds and interest into capital loans under Chapter 12 of the Companies Act, along with the loan drawn from Turret. More information on the arrangements is in the section of related-party transactions.

CASH FLOW

The Group's cash flow from operating activities during the review period was EUR -1.3 million (EUR -1.3 million). Operating cash flow development was positively affected by improved profitability, but was weakened by the change in working capital. In order to fasten the rate of turnover of trade receivables, the Group sells some of its trade receivables from Finnish customers. Some of the Swedish trade receivables are financed through factoring.

The Group's cash flow from financing activities during the review period was EUR 0.4 million (EUR 0.7 million), mainly consisting of related party loan withdrawals. Total change in cash during the review period was EUR -0.9 million (EUR -0.6 million).

GOODWILL

On 30 June 2025, the consolidated balance sheet recognised EUR 5.4 million (EUR 5.3 million) in goodwill. The company conducted an IAS 36 impairment test on its goodwill to reflect the status on 30 June 2025, and stated that there is no need to an impairment charge.

PERSONNEL

The average number of employees during the review period was 123 (125), and 123 (127) at the end of the period. At the end of the review period, 47 (55) of the Group's personnel were employed by the Finnish companies, and 76 (72) were employed in the Group's foreign companies.

SHARES AND SHARE CAPITAL*

Share turnover and price

During the review period, the company's share price hit a high of EUR 0.07 (EUR 0.02) and a low of EUR 0.01 (EUR 0.01), and the closing price on 30 June 2025 was EUR 0.03 (EUR 0.01). The average price during the review period was EUR 0.02 (EUR 0.01). During the review period, 84 188 413 (50 197 674) shares were traded, corresponding to 12.1 (7.2) per cent of the number of shares in circulation at the end of the review period. The Group's market capitalisation at the closing share price on 30 June 2025 was EUR 22 051 088 (5 270 072).

Share capital

At the beginning of the period under review, the company's registered share capital was EUR 585 394.16, and there were 693 430 455 shares. At the end of the period, the share capital was EUR 585 394.16, and there were 693 430 455 shares. The company has one class of shares. At the end of the reporting period, the company held a total of 7 664 943 treasury shares, 1.1% of all shares.

Option programmes 2021

The option rights belonging to the company's option program 2021 are marked with the codes 2021A1, 2021A2, 2021B1, 2021B2 and 2021C1. A maximum of 60,000,000 stock options can be issued and they entitle to subscribe for a maximum of 60,000,000 new shares of the Company. A total of 38,450,000 options belonging to the 2021A1 and 2021A2 series have been distributed among the options included in the option program. Series 2021A1 subscription period ended 31 December 2024. 29,900,000 of the distributed options have expired, so based on the terms of the option program, it is possible to subscribe for a maximum of 8,550,000 new shares of the Company.

The theoretical value of the options allocated by the end of review period is approximately EUR 0.8 million, which is recognised as an expense in accordance with IFRS 2 for the years 2021-2025. The expense recognition for 2025 is EUR 0.0 million. The expense recognition does not have cash flow impact.

Terms and conditions of option programs can be found at the Company's web site https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

*The information is presented as of 30 June, 2025, before the share consolidation on 15 August, 2025.

Shareholders

The number of shareholders on 30 June 2025 was 6 535 (5 616). Private individuals owned 12.4 (11.4) per cent of the shares, and institutions held 87.6 (88.6) per cent. Nominee-registered shares accounted for 12.4 (12.7) per cent of the total.

CHANGES IN THE GROUP STRUCTURE

Digitalist Open Tech AB internally sold 85% of its ownership in Digitalist Open Tech Oy to Digitalist Group Plc, the parent company of Digitalist Group, on 28 January 2025.

RELATED-PARTY TRANSACTIONS

Digitalist Group Plc restructures its financing 30 June 2025

Digitalist Group Plc agreed with Turret Oy Ab on a loan of EUR 800,000 to strengthen the Company's working capital. The Company has the right to draw down the Loan in instalments by 31 December 2025. The loan has been agreed on market terms and it is due for repayment on 31 December 2026.

Directed convertible capital bonds to Turret Oy Ab and Holdix Oy Ab in order to strengthen Digitalist Group's equity 30 June 2025

Convertible Bond 2025/1 to Turret Oy Ab

In accordance with the Terms and Conditions of the Convertible Bond 2025/1, Turret has paid the subscription price of the bond to the Company on 30 June 2025 by setting off the accrued interest from the Company's Convertible Bonds 2021/1, 2021/3 and 2022/1, total 2 617 363,41 euros.

Convertible Bond 2025/2 to Holdix Oy Ab

Holdix has paid the subscription price of the Convertible Bond 2025/2 to the Company on 30 June 2025 by setting off the accrued interest from the Company's Convertible Bonds 2021/2 and 2021/4, total 1 038 352,60 euros.

The stock exchange releases regarding the arrangements are on the company's website at https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

OTHER EVENTS DURING THE SECOND QUARTER

Annual General Meeting 29 April 2025

The company held its Annual General Meeting on 29 April 2025. The minutes of the Annual General Meeting and the decisions made are on the company's website at https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

The Annual General Meeting resolved that the loss EUR 5,520,249.94 indicated by the financial statements for 2024 be recorded in the Company's profit and loss account, and that no dividend be paid to shareholders for the financial period 2024.

The Annual General Meeting re-elected Paul Ehrnrooth, Andreas Rosenlew, Esa Matikainen, Peter Eriksson, Johan Almquist and Magnus Wetter as ordinary members of the Board of Directors. In its organizing meeting, the Board of Directors of Digitalist Group Plc resolved to elect Esa Matikainen as the chairman of the board of directors and Andreas Rosenlew as the vice chairman of the Board of Directors. The Board resolved to elect Esa Matikainen as chairman of the Audit Committee and Peter Eriksson and Magnus Wetter as members of the Audit Committee.

The Board of Directors has evaluated the independence of the Committee members in compliance with the recommendations of the Finnish Corporate Governance Code 2025 as follows. Esa Matikainen and Magnus Wetter are independent of the Company and independent of a significant shareholder. Peter Eriksson is independent of the Company and dependent on a significant shareholder.

Audit firm KPMG Oy Ab was appointed as the company's auditor, with KHT auditor Miika Karkulahti as the principal auditor.

Authorisation of the Board of Directors to decide on share issues and on granting special rights entitling to shares

The Annual General Meeting authorised the Board to decide on a paid share issue and on granting option rights and other special rights entitling to shares that are set out in Chapter 10 Section 1 of the Finnish Limited Liability Companies Act, or on the combination of all or some of the aforementioned instruments in one or more tranches on the following terms and conditions:

The total number of the Company's treasury shares and new shares to be issued under the authorisation may not exceed 346,715,227, which corresponds to approximately 50 per cent of all the Company's shares at the time of convening the Annual General Meeting.

Within the limits of the aforementioned authorisation, the Board of Directors may decide on all terms and conditions applied to the share issue and to the special rights entitling to shares, such as that the payment of the subscription price may take place not only by cash but also by setting off receivables that the subscriber has from the Company.

The Board of Directors shall be entitled to decide on crediting the subscription price either to the Company's share capital or, entirely or in part, to the invested unrestricted equity fund.

The share issue and the issuance of special rights entitling to shares may also take place in a directed manner in deviation from the pre-emptive rights of shareholders if there is a weighty financial reason for the Company to do so, as set out in the Limited Liability Companies Act. In such a case, the authorisation may be used to finance corporate acquisitions or other investments related to the operations of the Company as well as to maintain and improve the solvency of the Group and to carry out an incentive scheme.

The authorisation is proposed to be effective until the Annual General Meeting held in 2026, yet no further than until 30 June 2026.

Authorising the Board of Directors to decide on the acquisition and/or on the acceptance as pledge of the Company's treasury shares

The Annual General Meeting authorised the Board to decide on acquiring or accepting as pledge, using the Company's distributable funds, a maximum of 69,343,000 treasury shares, which corresponds to approximately 10 per cent of the Company's total shares at the time of convening the Annual General Meeting. The acquisition may take place in one or more tranches. The acquisition price shall not exceed the highest market price of the share in public trading at the time of the acquisition.

In executing the acquisition of treasury shares, the Company may enter into derivative, share lending or other contracts customary in the capital market, within the limits set out in laws and regulations. The authorisation entitles the Board to decide on an acquisition in a manner other than in a proportion to the shares held by the shareholders (directed acquisition).

The Company may acquire the shares to execute corporate acquisitions or other business arrangements related to the Company's operations, to improve its capital structure, or to otherwise further transfer the shares or cancel them.

The authorisation is proposed to include the right for the Board of Directors to decide on all other matters related to the acquisition of shares. The authorisation is proposed to be effective until the Annual General Meeting held in 2026, yet no further than until 30 June 2026.

Resolution on possible measures for improving the Company's financial situation

The financial statements presented to the Annual General Meeting for the fiscal year from January 1, 2024, to December 31, 2024, show that the Company's equity is less than half of the Company's share capital if the capital loans were not taken into account when assessing the matter.

It was noted that the Company has carried out the conversion, as announced on 30 December 2024, of the principal amounts and interests of the convertible bonds 2021/1, 2021/2, 2021/3, and 2021/4 entirely into capital loans in accordance with Chapter 12 of the Finnish Companies Act.

It was noted that these actions have supported and will support the Company's balance sheet and solvency.

It was resolved to accept the proposition of the Board of Directors of the Company not to implement immediate additional measures to rectify the Company's financial position, but the Company will actively evaluate other possibilities and means to support the Company's financial standing.

The stock exchange releases are on the company's website at https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

EVENTS SINCE THE REVIEW PERIOD

The Extraordinary General Meeting of Digitalist Group Plc

The Extraordinary General Meeting of Digitalist Group Plc was held on 13 August 2025 in Helsinki. The Extraordinary General Meeting resolved on the consolidation of the Company's shares, meaning a reduction in the number of shares, and on the related directed free share issue and redemption of shares without consideration, so that after the measures, each current 250 shares of the Company will correspond to one (1) share in the Company.

Authorisation of the Board of Directors to decide on share issues and on granting special rights entitling to shares

The Extraordinary General Meeting resolved to authorise the Board of Directors to decide on a share issue, which may be either against payment or without payment, as well as on granting option rights and other special rights entitling to shares that are set out in Chapter 10 Section 1 of the Finnish Limited Liability Companies Act, or on the combination of all or some of the aforementioned instruments in one or more tranches on the following terms and conditions:

The total number of the Company's treasury shares and new shares to be issued under the authorisation may not exceed 1,386,000 shares, which corresponds to approximately 50 percent of all the Company's shares following the share consolidation.

Within the limits of the aforementioned authorisation, the Board of Directors may decide on all terms and conditions applied to the share issue and to the special rights entitling to shares, such as that the payment of the subscription price may take place not only by cash but also by setting off receivables that the subscriber has from the Company.

In such a case, the authorisation may be used to finance corporate acquisitions or other investments related to the operations of the Company, to maintain and improve the solvency of the Group, and to carry out an incentive scheme.

The authorisation is valid until the Annual General Meeting to be held in 2026, however no later than 30 June 2026, and it cancels the corresponding authorisation granted by the Annual General Meeting on 29 April 2025.

Authorising the Board of Directors to decide on the acquisition and/or on the acceptance as pledge of the Company's treasury shares

The Extraordinary General Meeting resolved to authorise the Board of Directors to decide on acquiring or accepting as pledge, using the Company's distributable funds, a maximum of 270,000 treasury shares, which corresponds to approximately 10 percent of the Company's total shares following the share consolidation. In executing the acquisition of treasury shares, the Company may enter into derivative, share lending or other contracts customary in the capital market, within the limits set out in laws and regulations. The authorisation entitles the Board to decide on an acquisition in a manner other than in proportion to the shares held by the shareholders (directed acquisition).

The Company may acquire the shares to execute corporate acquisitions or other business arrangements related to the Company's operations, to improve its capital structure, or to otherwise further transfer the shares or cancel them.

The authorisation includes the right for the Board of Directors to decide on all other matters related to the acquisition of shares. The authorisation is valid until the Annual General Meeting to be held in 2026, however no later than 30 June 2026, and it cancels the corresponding authorisation granted by the Annual General Meeting on 29 April 2025.

Combination of Digitalist Group's Shares

On 15 August 2025, Digitalist Group Plc implemented, according to the Extraordinary General Meeting, the combination of the Company's shares, i.e. the reduction of the number of shares, as well as the related directed share issue without consideration, redemption of shares and cancellation of shares. Following the combination of shares, the Company's new total number of shares is 2,773,721. The convertible bonds and the 2021 Option Program were also adjusted accordingly to the share consolidation

The stock exchange releases are on the company's website at https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

RISK MANAGEMENT AND SHORT-TERM UNCERTAINTIES

The objectives of Digitalist Group Plc's risk management are to ensure the undisrupted continuity and development of the company's operations, support the achievement of the company's business objectives and increase the company's value. For more details about the organisation of risk management, processes and identified risks, see the company's website at https://investor.digitalistgroup.com

The company has been making a loss despite the efficiency measures it has taken. The company's loss-making performance directly affects its working capital and the sufficiency of its financing. This risk is managed by maintaining the capacity to use different financing solutions. The company aims to continuously assess and monitor the amount of necessary business financing to ensure that it has sufficient liquid assets to finance its operations and repay maturing loans. Any disruptions in the financial arrangements would weaken Digitalist Group's financial position.

The company is currently dependent on external financing, most of which has been obtained from related-party companies and financial institutions. Digitalist Group's ability to finance its operations and reduce the amount of its debt depends on several factors, such as the cash flow from operations and the availability of debt and equity financing, and there is no certainty that such financing will be available in the future. Similarly, there can be no certainty in the long term that Digitalist Group will be able to obtain additional debt or refinance its current debt on acceptable terms, if at all.

The convertible bonds and interest were converted into capital loans in two tranches in accordance with Chapter 12 of the Limited Liability Companies Act in 2024, strengthening the company's balance sheet. The balance sheet strengthening continued on 30 June 2025 by further converting interest into capital loans in accordance with Chapter 12 of the Companies Act. More information is in the section of related-party transactions.

Any changes to key client accounts could have a substantial impact on Digitalist Group's operations, earning potential and financial position. If one of Digitalist Group's largest clients decided to switch to a competing company or drastically altered its operating model, the chances of finding client volumes to replace the shortfall in the near term would be limited.

The Group's business consists mainly of individual client agreements, which are often relatively short-term. Forecasting the start dates and scopes of new products is occasionally challenging, while the cost structure is largely fixed. The aforementioned aspects can lead to unpredictable fluctuations in turnover and, thereby, in profitability. Some of the Group's business consists of fixed-price deliveries. Fixed-price client deliveries carry risks related to timing and content. The company endeavours to manage these risks through contractual and project management measures. Caution in customer demand and the competitive situation have partly led to an increased emphasis on price, which has a negative impact on margins both in the industry generally and for Digitalist Group specifically.

Irrespective of the market situation, there is a shortage of certain experts in the Group's business sector. Although the aggressive recruitment policies that occasionally arise in the Group's business sector have decreased, there is still a risk of personnel moving to competitors. A more significant risk, however, is related to the potential impact of cost-saving programs on employee engagement and retention. There are no guarantees that the company will be able to retain its current personnel and recruit new employees to sustain growth. If Digitalist Group loses a significant number of its current personnel, it would be more difficult to complete existing projects and acquire new ones. This could have an adverse impact on Digitalist Group's business, earnings and financial position.

The cost inflation has decreased but can still exert pressure to raise salaries, so the importance of cost monitoring is emphasised further. Variation in interest rates do not have a significant direct impact on financing costs because most of the company's debts have fixed interest rates. If the interest rates on the company's loans from financial institutions rose by 1 per cent, the company's annual interest costs would rise by approximately EUR 0.1 million.

Part of the Group's turnover is invoiced in currencies other than the euro - mainly in the Swedish krona. The risk associated with changes in exchange rates can be managed in various ways, including net positioning and currency hedging contracts. In 2024 and 2025, the Group had no hedging contracts.

The Group's balance sheet contains goodwill that is subject to impairment risk in the event that the Group's future yield expectations decrease due to internal or external factors. The goodwill is tested for impairment every six months and whenever the need arises.

General economic uncertainty and low growth forecasts in the company's key markets affected the Group's business during the financial period, but the future impact is difficult to estimate. Geopolitical uncertainty may affect the business activities of some of the Group's clients, thereby indirectly affecting the Group's business. The Group has no business activities in Russia or Ukraine.

LONG-TERM GOALS AND STRATEGY

Digitalist Group aims to achieve a profit margin of at least 10% over the long term. In order to achieve its long-term goals, Digitalist Group strives for profitable, international growth by shaping new forms of thinking, services and technological solutions for a variety of sectors. These sectors include, among others, the technology industry, energy industry, transport and logistics, as well as consumer services in both the public and private sectors. Digitalist Group's strategy focuses on enhancing its service and solution business and seamlessly integrating user and operational research, branding, design and technology.

NEXT REVIEW

The next interim report, for January-September 2025, will be published on 31 October 2025.

DIGITALIST GROUP PLC

Accounting principles

This interim report release has been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 - Interim Financial Reporting. The interim report release complies with the same accounting principles and calculation methods as the annual financial statements. The updates to the IFRS standards that entered into force on 1 January 2025 do not have a significant impact on the figures presented.

The preparation of a financial statement release in accordance with IFRS requires the management to use certain estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts recognised in assets and liabilities when the balance sheet was prepared, as well as the amounts of income and expenses in the period. In addition, discretion must be used in applying the accounting policies. As the estimates and assumptions are based on outlooks on the balance sheet date, they contain risks and uncertainties. The realised values may deviate from the original assessments and assumptions.

The original release is in Finnish. The English release is a translation of the original.

The figures in the release have been rounded, so the sums of individual figures may deviate from the presented totals. This interim report is unaudited.

Going concern

The Group's profitability has remained negative, and the financial situation has been challenging at times but the Half-Year review has been prepared in accordance with the principle of the business as a going concern. The assumption of continuity is based on management assumptions on several factors, including the following:

Revenue for the review period increased by 14.8% compared to the previous year, despite the challenging market situation. Revenue from the Finnish operations has also returned to growth after difficult yearsThe cost-saving programs have improved the Group's profitability. 30 June 2025 additional financing was arranged and the equity was strengthened.

When the review is published, the company expects its working capital to be sufficient to cover its requirements over the next 12 months based on the financing support provided by the main owner if needed.

Goodwill impairment testing

Digitalist Group tested its goodwill for impairment on 30 June 2025. The goodwill is allocated to one cash-generating unit. No need to write down goodwill was identified.

The value in use of the tested property exceeded the tested amount by EUR 2.1 million. The tested amount of goodwill in the balance sheet at the end of the review period is EUR 5.7 million.

The company tests its goodwill based on the utility value of the assets. In the testing conducted on 30 June 2024, the cash flow forecasting period was from 2025 to 2029. During the 2025-2029 forecasting period, average growth in revenue of 15.5% is expected to be achieved which is supported by the market growth of the group's industries and the increasingly extensive impact of digitalization in business life. In addition, the rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) and its integration into service offerings will accelerate growth by offering more efficient and innovative solutions to customers. The efficiency measures and strategic recruitment carried out provide a solid basis for growth. EBITDA is projected to rise to 8% in 2027 and to 12% by the end of the forecasting period.

The method involves comparing the tested assets with their cash flow over the selected period, taking into account the discount rate and the growth factor of the cash flows after the forecast period. The discount rate is 11.4% (11.4%). The growth factor used to calculate the cash flows after the forecast period is 2.35% (2.35%). The average EBITDA for the forecast period was used to calculate the value of the terminal period.

A significant negative change in individual assumptions used in the calculations can necessitate a goodwill impairment charge. The sensitivity analysis indicates that an impairment charge may be necessary if the average growth in turnover is below 14% in the forecasting period and the fixed cost structure does not change. If the EBITDA falls below 6% in the forecasting period or the WACC surpasses 15%, all else equal, impairment charges may become necessary.

data.title: Cognizant 在 Agentic AI 方面进行投资，并计划到 2026 年增加 1000 名上下文工程师
data.summary: Cognizant宣布投资Agentic AI，并计划到2026年增加1000名上下文工程师。此次投资和招聘计划旨在加速AI技术的发展和应用，进一步提升公司在人工智能领域的竞争力。上下文工程师将专注于开发能够理解和适应复杂环境的AI系统，推动AI技术在更多领域的应用。
data.content: (RTT新闻) - Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. (CTSH) 在周五宣布了一项旨在推进代理人工智能的举措，计划在明年部署约1,000名上下文工程师。该公司表示，此举将使上下文工程成为实现人工智能代理推理、行动和适应企业目标的重要学科。 作为该计划的一部分，Cognizant 表示，它将与 Workfabric AI 合作，后者通过 ContextFabric 平台将企业工作流、数据、规则和流程转化为可供人工智能代理采取行动的上下文。该公司补充说，ContextFabric 作为持续的接地层，使人工智能与实际执行模式保持一致，并使大规模的上下文工程成为可能。 Cognizant 表示，上下文工程技能将在其服务线中得到发展，并整合到其代理开发生命周期（ADLC）和企业代理化框架中。这种全面的方法确保人工智能代理能够有效地、安全地并大规模地运行。 借助 ContextFabric 的帮助，Cognizant 表示，其工程师将捕获企业知识、管理完整的上下文生命周期、构建集成管道、打包可重用的“上下文包”，并设计行业特定的蓝图。这些能力将帮助企业超越人工智能试点，从而加快价值实现速度并提高解决方案质量，该公司补充说。 Cognizant 首席执行官 Ravi Kumar S 对此表示：“凭借我们在工程、运营和行业领域的深厚专业知识，我们能够创造独特的价值。通过培训1,000名上下文工程师，并为他们配备 Workfabric AI 的 ContextFabric 平台，我们正在帮助我们的客户从实验转向可扩展的人工智能采用。”
data.aiInsight:
从技术发展角度来看，Cognizant 的这一举措体现了对代理人工智能技术的深入投资，尤其是在上下文工程领域的布局。上下文工程是将企业具体业务场景和知识转化为可供AI代理执行的上下文信息，这对提升AI代理的适应性和有效性至关重要。这一领域的投入预示着AI技术将更加注重实际应用场景的落地。

从行业影响来看，Cognizant 的这一战略选择可能会加速企业级AI解决方案的商业化进程。通过提供专业上下文工程师，Cognizant 可以帮助客户更高效地实现从AI试点到规模化应用的转变，从而推动整个行业对AI技术的实际应用和采纳。

展望未来趋势，随着企业对AI技术需求的增加，类似Cognizant这样的IT服务提供商可能会进一步扩大上下文工程师的规模，并开发更多针对不同行业和应用场景的解决方案。这不仅有助于提高AI解决方案的质量和效果，还将促进AI技术在更广泛的商业环境中得到应用。同时，也预示着对跨学科人才的需求将会增加，如数据科学家、业务分析师与软件工程师的结合，以更好地理解和构建复杂的AI系统。

data.content: 小米很高兴宣布其备受期待的REDMI 15C智能手机在尼日利亚市场的正式上市。该设备将于2025年8月29日起，通过全国所有授权的小米销售渠道和零售合作伙伴正式发售。 REDMI 15C专为尼日利亚消费者设计，重新定义了该类别智能手机的预期标准。凭借强大的硬件、优雅的设计和智能软件功能，REDMI 15C继续传承小米为用户提供卓越价值和创新的承诺，同时价格极具竞争力。 考虑到尼日利亚消费者的独特需求，尤其是在电力供应常常不可靠的市场中，小米为REDMI 15C配备了6000mAh的大容量电池——这是同类产品中容量最大的之一。 这款高容量电池确保用户可以从早上到晚上保持连接、娱乐和高效工作，而无需频繁充电。无论是参加虚拟会议、在线学习、观看视频，还是与家人和朋友聊天，REDMI 15C都能在最需要时提供动力。结合33W快充技术，停机时间显著减少，用户可以更快地回到重要事务上。 REDMI 15C配备了一块6.9英寸的大屏，提供真正的沉浸式视觉体验，从手掌中就能感受到电影般的视觉效果。对于尼日利亚热爱足球的群体来说，这款大屏非常适合观看现场比赛、在线观看高清电影或沉浸到最喜欢的电视节目中。 社交媒体爱好者和视频爱好者也会欣赏这款生动、沉浸式的屏幕，无论是滑动TikTok视频、Instagram Reels或YouTube内容，都能带来愉悦的体验。窄边框、高屏占比和鲜艳的色彩还原创造出全屏体验，既适合娱乐也适合日常生产力需求。 尽管内置了大电池和大屏幕，REDMI 15C仍保持了7.99毫米的纤薄和精致设计。其人体工程学设计确保了舒适的手感和便携性，使其既适合工作也适合娱乐。该设备有四种令人惊艳的颜色可供选择，以满足每种风格和个性的需求： REDMI 15C的设计语言体现了小米将美学与实用功能相结合的承诺，提供了一款用户可以自豪携带的智能手机。 REDMI 15C配备了强大的50MP AI双摄像头系统，让用户能够捕捉每一个细节和令人惊叹的清晰度。无论是记录特殊时刻、创建社交媒体内容，还是简单地拍摄日常生活中的回忆，智能摄像头系统都能根据不同光线和场景自动调整，提供专业级照片。 从肖像到风景，从白天到夜晚，REDMI 15C都能激发用户的创造力，提升他们的摄影水平。 在内部，REDMI 15C搭载了强大的八核处理器，确保在所有应用程序中提供流畅的性能。无论是多任务处理、玩休闲游戏，还是浏览网页，用户都能期望到可靠的响应和高效的性能，与他们的生活方式保持同步。 结合丰富的内存和存储配置——4GB + 128GB、6GB + 128GB 和 8GB + 256GB，用户可以根据自己的性能需求和使用模式选择合适的版本。 为庆祝REDMI 15C的上市，小米为尼日利亚的客户提供两项激动人心的促销活动： 现在购买REDMI 15C，将获赠一款小米品牌的雨伞，适用于雨季或晴天——既实用又时尚的配件。 与MTN尼日利亚合作，使用REDMI 15C和MTN SIM卡购买数据套餐的用户将获得50%的额外数据，为期六个月。这一举措确保用户可以保持连接、观看更多内容并在线上做更多事情，同时享受超值优惠。 REDMI 15C现在通过所有授权的小米商店在尼日利亚发售，包括Finet、Raya、3C Hub、Slot等。
